title: Creating custom import functions
text: can now try function look structure returned list.
code: library(dplyr) library(tidyr) library(eemR)  import_cary <- function(file) {   dat <- read.csv(file, nrows = 102L, skip = 1L)    ex <- na.omit(dat[, 1L])   em <- seq(50L, 330L, by = 5L)    em <- outer(ex, em, "+")   em <- as.vector(em)   ex <- rep(ex, 57L)    x <- dat[, -1L]   x <- x[-1L, ]    x <- matrix(     as.numeric(unlist(x, use.names = FALSE)),     ncol = 101L,     byrow = FALSE   )    res <- tibble(ex, em, x = as.vector(x)) |>     arrange(ex, em) |>     complete(ex, em, fill = list(x = NA))    ex <- sort(unique(ex))   em <- sort(unique(em))   x <- matrix(res$x, ncol = length(ex), byrow = TRUE)    # We need to interpolate because you do not have a regular grid (i.e.   # asynchronous)   r <- MBA::mba.surf(     res |> drop_na(),     no.X = 200L,     no.Y = 200L,     extend = FALSE   )    l <- list(     file = file,     x = t(r$xyz.est$z),     ex = r$xyz.est$x,     em = r$xyz.est$y   )    l }

title: Creating custom import functions
text: use import_function argument eem_read() function tell eemR read file. can visualize eem using plot() function:
code: str(import_cary(file)) #> List of 4 #>  $ file: chr "/home/runner/work/_temp/Library/eemR/extdata/custom_cary.csv" #>  $ x   : num [1:200, 1:200] 1.91 2.29 2.73 3.04 3.27 ... #>  $ ex  : num [1:200] 250 251 252 253 254 ... #>  $ em  : num [1:200] 300 302 305 307 310 ... eem <- eem_read(file, import_function = import_cary)  eem #>        sample ex_min ex_max em_min em_max is_blank_corrected #> 1 custom_cary    250    450    300    780              FALSE #>   is_scatter_corrected is_ife_corrected is_raman_normalized #> 1                FALSE            FALSE               FALSE

title: Introduction to eemR
text: Dissolved organic matter (DOM) plays central role functioning aquatic ecosystems. example, characteristics DOM pool (quantity quality) determine underwater light climate (Kirk 1994), composition aquatic microbial communities (Foreman Covert 2003; Kritzberg et al. 2006) carbon cycling local global scales (Cole et al. 2007). Chemically, DOM pool complex (> 1500 compounds) analytical methods used characterize relatively complex, time-consuming costly (Benner 2002; Seitzinger et al. 2005; Fellman, Hood, Spencer 2010). situation called development rapid cost effective characterization techniques. optical properties DOM can related chemical properties, optical techniques fluorescence spectroscopy developed rapidly adopted community characterize DOM pool aquatic ecosystems (Paula G. Coble et al. 1990; Paula G. Coble 1996; McKnight et al. 2001). seminal paper (Stedmon, Markager, Bro 2003) put forefront use parallel factor analysis (PARAFAC) aid characterization fluorescent DOM. Briefly, three-way technique allows decomposition complex DOM fluorescence signals contained excitation-emission matrix (EEM, Fig. 1) set individual chemical components provides estimations relative contribution total fluorescence (Bro 1997; Fellman, Hood, Spencer 2010; Stedmon, Markager, Bro 2003).  Example excitation-emission fluorescence matrix (EEM). diagonal structure high fluorescence corresponds first order Rayleigh scattering. PARAFAC model described (Bro 1997; Harshman 1970): xijk=∑f=1Faijbjfckf+eijkx_{ijk} = \sum_{f=1}^{F} a_{ij}b_{jf}c_{kf} + e_{ijk} =1,...,Ii = 1, ..., ; j=1,...,Jj = 1, ..., J; k=1,...,Kk = 1, ..., K, xijkx_{ijk} intensity fluorescence ithi^{th} sample jthj^{th} emission wavelength kthk^{th} excitation wavelength. aija_{ij} directly proportional concentration fthf^{th} component sample ii. Although PARAFAC gained lot attention environmental sciences, also widely used research fields medical, pharmaceutical, food, social information sciences (Murphy et al. 2013). today, 1850 published scientific papers relying PARAFAC identified Web Science. Although PARAFAC made easier using MATLAB toolbox (Murphy et al. 2013), preprocessing EEMs prior analysis still straightforward. EEM preprocessing important part PARAFAC since aims correct systematic bias measurements remove signal unrelated DOM fluorescence (Murphy et al. 2013). Biased models can produced steps conducted carefully (see Hiriart-Baer, Diep, Smith (2008) scattering fluorescence signals modeled wrongly interpreted). data processing cumbersome involves many steps (Stedmon Bro 2008; Murphy et al. 2013) usually executed hand within -house scripting therefore prone introduce errors. Another important drawback limiting effective preprocessing EEMs arise wide variety file formats provided different manufacturers spectrofluorometers makes data importation difficult generalize. Possibly reflecting difficulties, recently pointed characterization DOM using fluorescence spectroscopy still routinely included ecological studies (Fellman, Hood, Spencer 2010). Given increasing interest fluorescence spectroscopy ecology, tools needed unify main preprocessing steps needed analyzes PARAFAC metric calculations. purpose package provide rapid elegant interface perform preprocessing EEMs well extract common fluorescence-based metrics proposed literature obtain quantitative information DOM pool. paper presents theoretical mathematical background main PARAFAC preprocessing steps metric calculations concrete code examples.

title: Introduction to eemR
text: Main preprocessing steps using eemR package illustrated using subset three EEMs (Massicotte Frenette 2011). Briefly, EEMs (see Fig. 1 example) sampled St. Lawrence River, one largest rivers North America. Fluorescence matrices DOM measured Cary Eclipse spectrofluorometer (Varian, Mississauga, Ontario, Canada) excitation wavelengths 220 450 nm (5-nm increment) emission wavelengths 230 600 nm (2-nm increment). functions package start prefix 'eem_'. Importation EEMs done using eem_read() function. Given fluorescence files dependent spectrofluorometer used, determine automatically manufacturer files load accordingly. generic summary() function displays useful information : (1) wavelength ranges used emission excitation modes, (2) manufacturer file read (3) state EEM indicate corrections applied. surface plot EEMs made using plot(x, = 1) function index EEM plotted (see Fig. 3). Interactive plots using simple shiny app can lunched interactively browse EEMs. Subtraction water blank measured samples may help reduce scattering (Murphy et al. 2013; Stedmon Bro 2008). , done using eem_remove_blank(eem, blank) function eem list EEMs blank water blank. Scattering removal (Equation (2) Equation (3)) performed using eem_remove_scattering(eem, type, order, width) function eem list EEMs, type scattering type (raman rayleigh), order order scattering (1 2) width width nanometers slit windows removed. following example, first order Raman Rayleigh scattering removed using bandwidth 10 nm (Fig. 3).  Fluorescence profile pure water sample excitation 350 nm 300 450 nm emission. area Raman peak identified shaded polygon calculated using Equation (5). IFE correction requires use absorbance data (Equation (4)). EEM, absorbance spectra must supplied. easiest way provide absorbance use data frame column names matching EEMs names. following data frame, first column represents wavelengths absorbance measured whereas remaining columns absorbance spectra sample1, sample2 sample3. Note EEM names can obtained using eem_sample_names() function. IFE correction performed using eem_inner_filter_effect(eem, absorbance, pathlength) function eem list EEMs, absorbance data frame containing absorbance spectra pathlength absorbance cuvette pathlength expressed cmcm (Fig. 4B). EEM contained eem, ranges spanned IFE correction factors total absorbance AtotalA_{\text{total}} (Equation (4)) displayed user. can serve diagnostic tool determine mathematical correction appropriate method use handle IFE. Fig. 4 presents intermediate results obtained correction sample3. Note nonlinearity correction higher effect lower wavelengths (bottom-left corner panel C). corrected EEM presented Fig. 4D result operation dividing matrix 4A 4C. last step correction process consist calibrate fluorescence intensities using Raman scatter peak water (Lawaetz Stedmon 2009). performed using eem_raman_normalisation(eem, blank) function eem list EEMs blank water blank measured day. , water-blank used three EEMs. Note value Raman area (ArpA_{\text{rp}}, Equation(5)) printed. stage, corrections performed EEMs ready exported MATLAB PARAFAC analysis. state EEMs can verified using summary() function. drEEM MATLAB toolbox (Murphy et al. 2013) used perform PARAFAC analysis requires data specific format (structure). eem_export_matlab(file, ...) function can used export corrected EEMs PARAFAC ready format. first file argument mat file export structure second argument ... one eem object. exported, one can simply import generated mat file MATLAB using load('myfile.mat');. Coble’s peaks can extracted using eem_coble_peaks(eem) function. Note peaks , M, C, maximum fluorescence intensity range emission region returned. Fluorescence (FI), humification (HIX) biological (BIX) indices can extracted follow. noted different excitation emission wavelengths often used measure EEMs. Hence, possible mismatch measured wavelengths wavelengths used calculate specific metrics. circumstances, EEMs interpolated using package (Borchers 2015). message warning user displayed data interpolation performed. behavior can controlled using verbose = TRUE/FALSE parameter.

code: file <- system.file("extdata/cary/scans_day_1", package = "eemR") eems <- eem_read(file, import_function = "cary") summary(eems) #>    sample ex_min ex_max em_min em_max is_blank_corrected is_scatter_corrected #> 1    nano    220    450    230    600              FALSE                FALSE #> 2 sample1    220    450    230    600              FALSE                FALSE #> 3 sample2    220    450    230    600              FALSE                FALSE #> 4 sample3    220    450    230    600              FALSE                FALSE #>   is_ife_corrected is_raman_normalized #> 1            FALSE               FALSE #> 2            FALSE               FALSE #> 3            FALSE               FALSE #> 4            FALSE               FALSE plot(eems, which = 3L) plot(eems, interactive = TRUE)

title: Introduction to eemR
text: Subtraction water blank measured samples may help reduce scattering (Murphy et al. 2013; Stedmon Bro 2008). , done using eem_remove_blank(eem, blank) function eem list EEMs blank water blank.
code: file <- system.file("extdata/cary/scans_day_1", "nano.csv", package = "eemR") blank <- eem_read(file, import_function = "cary")  eems <- eem_remove_blank(eems, blank)

title: Introduction to eemR
text: Scattering removal (Equation (2) Equation (3)) performed using eem_remove_scattering(eem, type, order, width) function eem list EEMs, type scattering type (raman rayleigh), order order scattering (1 2) width width nanometers slit windows removed. following example, first order Raman Rayleigh scattering removed using bandwidth 10 nm (Fig. 3).  Fluorescence profile pure water sample excitation 350 nm 300 450 nm emission. area Raman peak identified shaded polygon calculated using Equation (5).
code: eems <- eem_remove_scattering(eems, "rayleigh", 1L, 10L) |>   eem_remove_scattering("raman", 1L, 10L)  plot(eems, which = 3L)

title: Introduction to eemR
text: IFE correction requires use absorbance data (Equation (4)). EEM, absorbance spectra must supplied. easiest way provide absorbance use data frame column names matching EEMs names. following data frame, first column represents wavelengths absorbance measured whereas remaining columns absorbance spectra sample1, sample2 sample3. Note EEM names can obtained using eem_sample_names() function. IFE correction performed using eem_inner_filter_effect(eem, absorbance, pathlength) function eem list EEMs, absorbance data frame containing absorbance spectra pathlength absorbance cuvette pathlength expressed cmcm (Fig. 4B). EEM contained eem, ranges spanned IFE correction factors total absorbance AtotalA_{\text{total}} (Equation (4)) displayed user. can serve diagnostic tool determine mathematical correction appropriate method use handle IFE. Fig. 4 presents intermediate results obtained correction sample3. Note nonlinearity correction higher effect lower wavelengths (bottom-left corner panel C). corrected EEM presented Fig. 4D result operation dividing matrix 4A 4C.
code: data("absorbance") head(absorbance) #>   wavelength sample1 sample2 sample3 #> 1        190 0.89674 1.02927 1.19405 #> 2        191 0.84894 0.96381 1.13721 #> 3        192 0.77267 0.85339 1.04520 #> 4        193 0.70967 0.75627 0.96782 #> 5        194 0.65459 0.67145 0.90092 #> 6        195 0.61371 0.60745 0.85054 eem_names(eems) #> [1] "nano"    "sample1" "sample2" "sample3" eems <- eem_inner_filter_effect(   eem = eems,   absorbance = absorbance,   pathlength = 1L ) #> Warning: Absorbance spectrum for nano was not found. Returning uncorrected EEM. #> sample1  #> Range of IFE correction factors: 1.0112 1.5546  #> Range of total absorbance (Atotal) : 0.0096 0.3832  #>  #> sample2  #> Range of IFE correction factors: 1.0061 1.3124  #> Range of total absorbance (Atotal) : 0.0053 0.2362  #>  #> sample3  #> Range of IFE correction factors: 1.016 2.3713  #> Range of total absorbance (Atotal) : 0.0138 0.75  plot(eems, which = 3L)

title: Introduction to eemR
text: last step correction process consist calibrate fluorescence intensities using Raman scatter peak water (Lawaetz Stedmon 2009). performed using eem_raman_normalisation(eem, blank) function eem list EEMs blank water blank measured day. , water-blank used three EEMs. Note value Raman area (ArpA_{\text{rp}}, Equation(5)) printed. stage, corrections performed EEMs ready exported MATLAB PARAFAC analysis. state EEMs can verified using summary() function.
code: eems <- eem_raman_normalisation(eems, blank) #> Raman area: 9.540904  #> Raman area: 9.540904  #> Raman area: 9.540904  plot(eems, which = 3L) summary(eems) #>    sample ex_min ex_max em_min em_max is_blank_corrected is_scatter_corrected #> 1    nano    220    450    230    600              FALSE                 TRUE #> 2 sample1    220    450    230    600               TRUE                 TRUE #> 3 sample2    220    450    230    600               TRUE                 TRUE #> 4 sample3    220    450    230    600               TRUE                 TRUE #>   is_ife_corrected is_raman_normalized #> 1            FALSE               FALSE #> 2             TRUE                TRUE #> 3             TRUE                TRUE #> 4             TRUE                TRUE

title: Introduction to eemR
text: drEEM MATLAB toolbox (Murphy et al. 2013) used perform PARAFAC analysis requires data specific format (structure). eem_export_matlab(file, ...) function can used export corrected EEMs PARAFAC ready format. first file argument mat file export structure second argument ... one eem object. exported, one can simply import generated mat file MATLAB using load('myfile.mat');.
code: eem_export_matlab("myfile.mat", eems)

title: Introduction to eemR
text: Coble’s peaks can extracted using eem_coble_peaks(eem) function. Note peaks , M, C, maximum fluorescence intensity range emission region returned. Fluorescence (FI), humification (HIX) biological (BIX) indices can extracted follow. noted different excitation emission wavelengths often used measure EEMs. Hence, possible mismatch measured wavelengths wavelengths used calculate specific metrics. circumstances, EEMs interpolated using package (Borchers 2015). message warning user displayed data interpolation performed. behavior can controlled using verbose = TRUE/FALSE parameter.
code: file <- system.file("extdata/cary/scans_day_1", package = "eemR") eems <- eem_read(file, import_function = "cary")  eem_coble_peaks(eems, verbose = FALSE) #>    sample         b         t        a          m         c #> 1    nano 0.8745673 0.1401188 0.140175 0.09653326 0.1255788 #> 2 sample1 1.5452981 1.0603312 3.731836 2.42409567 1.8149415 #> 3 sample2 1.2629968 0.6647042 1.583489 1.02359302 0.7709074 #> 4 sample3 1.4740862 1.3162812 8.416034 6.06335506 6.3179129 eem_fluorescence_index(eems, verbose = FALSE) #>    sample         fi #> 1    nano -0.5932057 #> 2 sample1  1.2647823 #> 3 sample2  1.4553330 #> 4 sample3  1.3294132  eem_humification_index(eems, verbose = FALSE) #>    sample        hix #> 1    nano  0.5568136 #> 2 sample1  6.3795618 #> 3 sample2  4.2548483 #> 4 sample3 13.0246234  eem_biological_index(eems, verbose = FALSE) #>    sample       bix #> 1    nano 2.6812045 #> 2 sample1 0.7062640 #> 3 sample2 0.8535423 #> 4 sample3 0.4867927

title: Introduction to eemR
text: provides flexible interface manipulating preprocessing fluorescence matrices based theoretical mathematical foundations fluorescence spectroscopy (Lakowicz 2006). Furthermore, package removes drawbacks associated EEM manipulation (dependent spectrofluorometer manufacturer) unifies important steps involved EEM preparation order correct remove systematic bias fluorescence measurements. likely contribute promote use fluorescence spectroscopy various fields.

title: Blank correction — eem_remove_blank
code: ## Example 1  # Open the fluorescence eem file <- system.file("extdata/cary/scans_day_1", "sample1.csv", package = "eemR") eem <- eem_read(file, import_function = "cary")  plot(eem)   # Open the blank eem file <- system.file("extdata/cary/scans_day_1", "nano.csv", package = "eemR") blank <- eem_read(file, import_function = "cary")  plot(blank)   # Remove the blank eem <- eem_remove_blank(eem, blank)  plot(eem)   ## Example 2  # Open the fluorescence eem folder <- system.file("extdata/cary/scans_day_1", package = "eemR") eems <- eem_read(folder, import_function = "cary")  plot(eems, which = 3)   # Open the blank eem file <- system.file("extdata/cary/scans_day_1", "nano.csv", package = "eemR") blank <- eem_read(file, import_function = "cary")  plot(blank)   # Remove the blank eems <- eem_remove_blank(eems, blank)  plot(eems, which = 3)   # Automatic correction folder <- system.file("extdata/cary/", package = "eemR")  # Look at the folder structure list.files(folder, "*.csv", recursive = TRUE) #> [1] "scans_day_1/nano.csv"    "scans_day_1/sample1.csv" #> [3] "scans_day_1/sample2.csv" "scans_day_1/sample3.csv" #> [5] "scans_day_2/blank.csv"   "scans_day_2/s1.csv"       eems <- eem_read(folder, recursive = TRUE, import_function = "cary") res <- eem_remove_blank(eems) #> A total of 1 blank EEMs will be averaged. #> A total of 1 blank EEMs will be averaged.

title: eemR 1.0.2

Allow eem_bind() accept list eemlists (#66 #64) @jpshanno Correction functions modify name eem (#53 #56). eem_humification_index() now ignore missing values (example due scattering removal) calculation. Increasing code coverage 40% 55%.

title: eemR 1.0.1

title: eemR 1.0.0
text: eemR can use user-defined function import eems data. new argument import_function eem_read() function can used provide custom function read specific eem file format.

title: eemR 1.0.0
text: major change eem_read(), existing code brake. user still can uses old importing functions specifying spectrofluorometer use follows: eem_read(file, import_function = "cary") eem_read(file, import_function = "aqualog") eem_read(file, import_function = "shimadzu") eem_read(file, import_function = "fluoromax4")

title: eemR 1.0.0
text: New function eem_peaks() extract user-defined fluorescence peaks (#42).

title: eemR 0.1.5
text: CRAN release: 2017-05-08 Improved plot visualization look feel produced Matlab DrEEM. Use file name name eem. Reading Cary Eclipse files robust detecting correct excitation wavelengths. eemR can now read Fluoromax-4 files (#40). eem_cut() gains logical argument exact. TRUE, wavelengths matching em /ex removed. FALSE, wavelengths range em /ex removed. Taking account cuvette size calculate 1.5 threshold proposed Kothawala correcting IFE. Inner-filter effect correction factors now corrected correctly. fluorescence assumed measured 1 cm cuvette, absorbance now expressed per centimeter. Better guessing number columns fluorescence matrix produced Cary Eclipse software. Fixed many typos.

title: eemR 0.1.4
text: CRAN release: 2016-08-29 eem_extract() now intuitive use. remove argument replace keep. TRUE, specified samples returned. FALSE, removed (#37). eem_cut() now removes specified wavelengths instead keeping . eem_cut() gains argument fill_with_na. TRUE fluorescence specified wavelengths replaced NA instead removed. File structure now kept performing inner-filter effect correction (#35). Now using viridis space colors plotting EEMs instead color jet. eem_remove_scattering() longer tolower absorbance names assume provided absorbance spectra match exactly EEM’s names. Fixing bug prevented interactive plot work properly. summary(x) print(x) now return data frame containing summarized information EEMs contained x. See ?summary.eemlist. eem_raman_normalisation() eem_remove_blank() average blank EEMs one provided found folder (#23). eem_raman_normalisation(), eem_remove_blank() eem_inner_filter_effect() now verify correction already performed. , unmodified EEM returned. eem_raman_normalisation() now interpolates blank EEM ensure em 350 excitation 371 428 exist (#31). eem_remove_blank() eem_raman_normalisation() now keep blank samples automatic correction used. automatic correction used, untransformed blank sample keep list. error now occur trying perform blank correction Raman normalization.

title: eemR 0.1.3
text: CRAN release: 2016-05-02 Interactive plot using simple shiny app. Using plot(eems, interactive = TRUE) lunch shiny app allows interactively browse EEMs contained eems. vignette added package can viewed using vignette(topic = "introduction", package = "eemR"). error occur one try raman normalization blank scattering bands removed. eem_sample_names() replaced eem_names(). Reading Aqualog files now ~20% faster (#26). plot() gains argument show_peaks = TRUE/FALSE can used display common fluorescence peaks used literature. eem_remove_blank() eem_raman_normalisation() can now try implicitly use blank eem eemlist object (#20). blank omitted (blank = NA), functions try extract blank eemlist object. done looking sample names containing one complete partial strings (ignoring case): - “nano” - “miliq” - “milliq” - “mq” - “blank” Consider following example two folders represent scans performed two different days scans_day_1 scans_day_2. folder three samples one blank files. context, eem_remove_blank() use blank nano.csv sample1.csv, sample2.csv sample3.csv. strategy used files folder scans_day_2 blank named blank.csv. eem_extract() now argument verbose (default = FALSE) determine names removed extracted eems printed screen. Implemented generic print() method calls summary(). Added tests packages verify metrics. Now better estimate number columns read Cary Eclipse files (#27). also makes reading much faster.
code: inst/extdata/cary/ ├── scans_day_1 │   ├── nano.csv │   ├── sample1.csv │   ├── sample2.csv │   └── sample3.csv └── scans_day_2     ├── blank.csv     └── s1.csv

title: eemR 0.1.2
text: CRAN release: 2016-02-04 Sample names now exported using eem_export_matlab() function. New function eem_bind() implemented merge objects class eem eemlist. Reading EEMs ~ 50% faster. New function eem_sample_names() implemented. eem_sample_names(eem) returns vector containing sample names EEMs. eem_sample_names(eem) <- c(...) sets sample names EEMs. eem_extract() now argument ignore_case (#10) specify regular expression search ignore sample name case (TRUE) (FALSE). Sample names (.e. file names) now verified make.names() (#15). Various improvements documentation.

title: eemR 0.1.0
text: CRAN release: 2015-11-19 First version eemR
